Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

ALLEGATION:
Youth A has a history of aggressive behavior and was advancing on Staff 1 on
6/4/22. Youth later reported slipping and falling with Staff 1. Youth had bruising to
one of their arms and had arm pain. On 6/5/22, youth was taken for medical care
and was diagnosed with a broken humorous. On 6/6/22, youth reported that Staff 1
pushed them and tripped them, causing the injury.
INVESTIGATION:
Case Manager was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 6/6/22. He
reported the incident with Youth A took place on Saturday 6/4/22 and involved Staff
1. There were no eyewitnesses to the allegations except for Staff 1 who had no
initial report of injury to Youth A but later reported the injury took place around 12:20
pm. Case Manager became aware of the injury when informed by Staff 10, after he
was informed by Youth A at approximately 4:40 pm. Case Manager observed the
injuries and found bruising on Youth A's chest, collarbone, and left arm. Youth A told
Case Manager, Staff 1 had hit him and pushed him into a wall. Youth A also said the
inside of his left elbow hurt. Case Manager began treatment with ice and Tylenol
and noticed Youth A was not using his left arm as much as in the past. The next
morning Case Manager checked on Youth A and found the symptoms had not
improved so he was taken to the hospital. Case Manager also reported speaking
with Staff 1 and being told Youth A was being aggressive towards him when Youth A
slipped twice and fell to the ground, which Staff 1 believed caused the injury. He was
told Staff 2 was in the dining room during the incident and looked into the room
where Youth A and Staff 1 were engaged in the allegations. Staff 4 was also in the
dining room. Staff 2 informed Case Manager Staff 1 texted her about the incident
after their shift. Case Manager provided the contact information for staff working at
the time of the incident that included Nurse, Staff 3, Staff 4, Staff 5, Staff 6, Staff 7,
Staff 8, Staff 9, and Staff 10.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on 6/6/22. Youth A has
limited verbal skills, but he reported his arm hurt and he showed his cast on his left
arm. He also reported being pushed by Staff 1 as the reason for his hurt arm.

Administrator and Case Manager were interviewed via telephone, on 6/7/22 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Both report receiving information of Youth A's
injuries at 4:40 pm the day it occurred but Staff 1 should have reported it when it
occurred according to policies/procedures. Both gave the same report of how they
were informed of the injuries. Case Manager reported speaking to Staff 1 after 5:00
pm and writing the incident report from information provided by Staff 1. He was
concerned with Youth A's health and forgot to ask Staff 1 why he did not write an
incident report. Administrator reported Youth A was taken to the hospital on Sunday
6/5/22 and received information that Staff 2 wanted to tell her what really happened.
Case Manager informed Staff 1 he would not be working with Youth A on Sunday
and later informed him he was suspended during the investigation. Staff 1 would
need to provide an account of what occurred. They received a written report from
Staff 1 and spoke with Staff 2 gathering information about the incident. Staff 1
denied any wrongdoing in his report and Staff 2 informed them; Staff 1 wanted to
hurt Youth A. Both Staff 1 and Staff 2 admitted to being in a romantic relationship
that ended a couple of weeks ago when Administrator and Case Manager became
aware of the relationship. This type of relationship is not allowed by
policy/procedures. Staff 2 provided a copy of the text messages she was having with
Staff 1 about the allegations. These text message begin on Saturday 6/4/22 and end
on Sunday 6/5/22. Administrator reported there are several violations of the facility's
phone policy and HIPPA policies within the text messages. Both believe Staff 2 is
trying to cover up Staff 1's behaviors at the beginning of the text message but later
questions him. It appears upon learning about the broken bone, Staff 2 started
sharing what she knew was the truth about the allegations. Both reported there are
cameras in the facility, but they are not allowed to record only current view is allowed
by Community Mental Health restrictions.
Staff 7 was interviewed via telephone, on 7/11/22 in collaboration with MDHHS
worker. She reported being told by Staff 1 "weeks before" the incident, he would
"put hands on" Youth A if Youth A ever touched Staff 2 again. She was working the
day and shift of the incident. She was supervising another youth who was on one-
on-one, and her involvement was watching the camera footage. She noticed Youth
A was in a "safety separation" with Staff 1 being his primary staff at the time. The
safety separation was taking place in the Hearth room and Staff 7 noticed Staff 1
was staying in the room longer than what he should have been. Staff 7 described
staff's involvement and positioning when there is a safety separation with a youth.
"Normally staff and everyone else leave the room because they are trying to
deescalate the youth". Staff 7 over heard Youth A making sounds that he normally
makes when becoming aggressive with someone while Staff 1 was in the room with
Youth A. She was unsure why Staff 1 was staying in the room so long and several
times, Staff 1 was asked to leave the room to help Youth A deescalate. She also
reported that once she changed positions that day, she became the lead staff and
Staff 1 told her he wanted to stay and work through the safe separation with Youth A
rather than switch out with the next staff. Staff are to switch out every hour during a
safety separation. She told Staff 1 that staff are not to "work through things" with
youth. Staff 1 continued to "hang around" before she had him leave the building in

such a way; he had no further contact with Youth A. Staff 7 reported Youth A told
Staff 10 who replaced Staff 1 that he had a "boo boo" because Staff 1 hurt his arm
when Staff 1 pushed him to the floor near a door in the room. Staff 7 informed Case
Manager and Case Manager spoke with Youth A about the allegations of Staff 1
pushing him. Staff 13 also came into the area and checked Youth A. Staff 7 reported
knowing Staff 1 and Staff 2 were in a relationship and believes Staff 1’s response to
Youth A maybe a result of this relationship because Youth A had touched Staff 2
sexually. She believes Staff 1 wanted to work with Youth A but over time he did not
want to work with him any longer. Staff 7 reported being told by Staff 2 the night of
the incident that she was "super conflicted" knowing things about the incident that
others did not know. Staff 7 encouraged Staff 2 to report what she knew about the
incident to others because she is a mandated reporter. Staff 7 never knew what
information Staff 2 had until they reported this information to Case Manager the next
day when Staff 7 accompanied her. Staff 7 texted Administrator about midnight
(night of incident) to inform her of Staff 2 having further information.
Staff 9 was interviewed via telephone, on 7/11/22 in collaboration with MDHHS
worker. She reported working at the facility the day of the incident from 1:00 pm to
10:00 pm. When she arrived at work, Youth A was in a safety separation in the
Hearth room and "making sounds like he was aggressing towards someone". Staff
are to stay out of the area when a youth is in a safety separation, but she was
unaware of who was in the room with Youth A. After lunch Staff 9 "switched to
medication passing" and Youth A told her his elbow was hurt. Throughout the shift
Staff 9 worked, Youth A complained of pain in his elbow, so she gave him an ice
pack. Youth A would not let Staff 9 examine his arm or touch him. Staff 9 called
Case Manager to inform him of the injury and lack of movement of Youth A's arm.
She was told to write an incident report and monitor Youth A. Case Manager told her
if the pain and lack of movement grows worst within the next 24-hours, Youth A
should be taken to the hospital. She reported not knowing of any past issues
between Staff 1 and Youth A other than Youth A disliked Staff 1.
Staff 10 was interviewed via telephone, on 7/11/22 in collaboration with
MDHHS worker. He reported working the day of the incident on second shift which
began between 2:30 pm and 2:45 pm. He was scheduled to work with Youth A and
took over for Staff 1 but did not notice anything out of normal. Youth A told him his
arm hurt because Staff 1 pushed him. At first Staff 10 "didn't think much of it",
because in the past Youth A seeks ways to get to the hospital. However, this time,
Youth A was showing a different type of pain and Staff 10 observed a mark on his
collarbone. The mark turned out to be a bruise, so Staff 10 called Staff 7 and said
she needed to inform Case Manager right away. They observed Youth A and
noticed very limited arm movement and a "rug burn" on his chest and marks on his
left elbow. Staff 10 also reported Case Manager took Youth A into the bathroom for
privacy but failed to observe the same bruising that Staff 10 observed. Staff 10 is
unsure why they were not seeing the same thing and he believes Case Manager
was "not fully understanding what was going on". Staff 10 believed the nurse should
have been called because of the medical knowledge but he is unsure if this

occurred. Staff 10 denied knowing or hearing of any issues between Staff 1 and
Youth A.
Staff 12 was interviewed via telephone, on 7/11/22 in collaboration with
MDHHS worker. She reported not working the day of the incident but working the
day after and noticed Staff 1 was working that morning and offered to come back
into work later that night. During the second shift and the return from the hospital by
Youth A, Staff 1 asked her about Youth A going to the hospital because "his injury
didn't look that bad". When Youth A observed Staff 1 "Youth A began aggressing
towards Staff 1" and ran up to him and started punching him. Staff 12 told him to
leave the area. Staff 12 refused to leave Staff 1 alone with Youth A and she sent
Staff 1 home. She reported earlier during first shift she noticed Youth A was not
using his left arm and told her Staff 1 had hurt him. His arm looked limp and felt cold
to the touch. She observed his collarbone area and found bruising. She took pictures
and called Administrator who was the "On-call manager" at the time. Administrator
told her it was reported Youth A was using his arm yesterday but should take him to
the hospital now. Staff 12 sent the pictures of bruising and injuries to Case Manager
because he had observed the bruising yesterday. Staff 12 described Staff 1 as
having a "poor attitude towards Youth A" and will escalate Youth A.
Staff 11 was interviewed via telephone, on 7/11/22 in collaboration with
MDHHS worker. He reported working the first shift the day after the incident and
upon learning about the injuries, instructed another staff to write an incident report.
Staff 14 was working with Youth A that morning and called Staff 11 after noticing
bruising and a lack of movement in the left arm. Youth A was given pain medication
and taken to the hospital later that day. He believed Staff 1 and Youth A had a
"decent relationship" prior to the incident.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone, on 7/12/22 in collaboration with MDHHS
worker. She reported being present when the incident took place. She was in the
dining room which is next door to the Hearth room where Staff 1 and Youth A were
located at the time. She overheard noise and "peeked" her head out of the door.
Staff 1 told her Youth A slipped on water and fell to the floor. Staff 1 also told her this
occurred before he knew what happened. She does not remember seeing water and
just "took his word for it". She also reported, Staff 1 never said there was not water
on the floor, but she believed "it was clear there was no water" after speaking to him
later that day. She also believes Staff 1 should have left Youth A in the room alone
because he was in a safety separation and would only escalate. She told Staff 4
about Staff 1 staying in the room and Staff 4 also looked out of the dining room door
about three times. She texted Staff 1 to ask what was going on and Staff 1 replied
he will tell her later tonight. She also reported being informed by Staff 1 of what
occurred in text messages (a review of these text messages is below) and speaking
to him that evening. Staff 1 informed her he got annoyed with Youth A because of
his behaviors such as touching others faces. Youth A began to hit him, and every
time Youth A tried to kick him, Staff 1 would move his foot under Youth A's foot
causing him to fall, landing on his left arm (this is the arm he broke). Staff 1 told Staff

2 he lost count of the number of times Youth A fell to the ground and grew tired of
this because Youth A continued to get up. Staff 1 then reported to Staff 2, he put an
arm guard on and was able to grab Youth A by his shoulder while flexing his
collarbone. He was able to get his fingers under Youth A's collarbone and began
pulling him around and pushing him by the collarbone. Staff 1 said he "wanted to
make Youth A's last days at the center a living hell and he wanted to kill him". Staff 2
was unsure how serious Staff 1 was with these statements. Staff 1 also told her he
could have done more and wanted to see the safety separation all the way through.
He ended by telling her he did this for her. Staff 2 reported a belief Staff 1 was trying
to protect her because they were in a relationship and Youth A had become sexually
aggressive with her. Youth A was targeting her and would try to rip off her clothes or
touch her breasts or genital area. She was able to speak to her supervisor and
restrictions were put into place which stopped her having contact with Youth A. She
believes, Staff 1 did not see her receiving any support and took matters into his own
hands. Staff 2 also reported she supported Staff 1 until he shared information about
what occurred the evening of the incident and her view changed. Staff 2 reported
speaking to Case Manager after Youth A went to the hospital and wrote an incident
report. She believed Case Manager was downplaying the injury because he was
friends with Staff 1 prior to his promotion.
Staff 14 was interviewed via telephone, on 7/15/22 in collaboration with
MDHHS worker. He reported not working the day of the incident but working first
shift the next day. He noticed a difference in Youth A immediately because Youth A
was not targeting others and when aggressing he was not using his left arm. Youth
A told him he needs to go to the doctor because his left arm is hurting. The lead staff
(Staff 15) was informed along with the on-call manager. Staff 15 called upper
management and Staff 14 was told to monitor Youth A. This took place around 9:00
AM. When Youth A took off his shirt for a shower, Staff 14 noticed significant
bruising on his shoulder and around the collarbone area. Staff 14 described the
bruising as "not normal". Staff 11 was present and observed the significant bruising
and both staff showed the bruising to Staff 15. Staff 14 asked other staff who worked
the day before if they knew anything about the situation and Staff 1 said he was the
staff on duty during the safety separation with Youth A. Staff 1 told him, Youth A
slipped twice and fell to the floor while trying to kick Staff 1. Staff 14 also reported
"accepting Staff 1 statements about what occurred but he still questioned the
significant bruising on the collarbone area. Staff did what they could to help Youth A
with the pain and later that day at approximately 9:00 PM, Staff 14 called back to get
an update on Youth A and was told he was at the hospital. Staff 14 reported staff
should only enter a room a youth in a safety separation is in for compliance checks
and when the youth is no longer escalated.
Staff 6 was interviewed via telephone, on 7/15/22 in collaboration with MDHHS
worker. He reported working the day of the incident and with Youth A specifically
from 7:00 to 12:00 that morning. He then switched to work with another youth and
reported staff only work with Youth A for a 4-hour period because of his aggression.
Staff 6 was in a "back office" and did not observe what was occurring with Youth A

when Staff 1 was with him. He also reported working the next day but having no
information about what occurred. He only heard rumors of Youth A's arm being
broken.
Staff 8 was interviewed via telephone, on 7/15/22 in collaboration with MDHHS
worker. She reported working as a cook on the day of the incident but has no
firsthand knowledge of what occurred. She also reported not hearing any noise from
Hearth room which is next to the dining room.
Staff 5 was interviewed via telephone, on 7/15/22 in collaboration with MDHHS
worker. She reported working the day of the incident and the next day. She also
reported having no knowledge of what occurred and never observed anything
inappropriate.
Staff 4 was interviewed via telephone, on 7/15/22 in collaboration with MDHHS
worker. He reported working the day of the incident and having some interaction
with Staff 1. He was in the dining room and several times looked through the doors
leading to the Hearth room. He told Staff 1, who was staying in the environment
longer than necessary to leave but having Staff 1 not leave for several minutes later.
This occurred several times with no reason for Staff 1 to stay in the environment "a
second longer than he was". He never observed water on the floor and never
observed Staff 1 do anything inappropriate. He did hear Youth A making aggressive
noises repeatedly. Staff 4 also reported staff are to stay out of the environment
during a safety separation unless the situation becomes unsafe for the youth.
Staff 15 was interviewed via telephone, on 7/15/22 in collaboration with
MDHHS worker. He reported working the day after the incident occurred. He
observed Youth A and found him to not be using his left arm and complaining of
pain. He reported he did not observe any bruising because he was only looking for
movement in Youth A’s arm. Youth A was taken to the hospital after Staff 15 had
finished his shift.
Staff 13 was interviewed via telephone, on 7/15/22 in collaboration with
MDHHS worker. He reported working the day of the incident but at 8:00 PM. He
was given information from Staff 7 and Staff 9 about Youth A's injuries, and both
asked him to observe these injuries on Youth A. Staff 13 also reported not being a
medical expert, but he did check Youth A. He described the bruising in the
collarbone area as being caused by deep broken blood vessels and possible
bruising of the collarbone. He did not observe any evidence of a broken bone in
Youth A's arm, but he informed them Youth A should be taken to the hospital to be
checked out by a doctor. Staff 13 reported any staff can "make the call" to take a
youth to the hospital if they suspect an injury that needs immediate medical
attention. He was not sure if Staff 7 and Staff 9 had the medical training that most
lead staff had because of the rate of staff turn over the facility has experienced
lately. Staff 13 also reported Youth A told him Staff 1 pushed him. When talking with

Staff 6 regarding reporting Staff 1's behavior, Staff 6 state, "how can you do that to
another employee".
Several attempts were made to interview Staff 1, but these attempts were
unsuccessful.
MDHHS worker reported the individual was deemed unsuitable.
Documents Reviewed:
Pictures of Youth A without a date but received on 7/11/22. Both pictures are of
Youth A’s right collarbone and show extensive bruising. The bruising is the size of
the fist.
Behavior Treatment Plan Youth A date of report 2/23/22. Youth A is diagnoses
with Autism Spectrum Disorder, Conduct Disorder, and Mild Intellectual Disability.
He is currently prescribed Abilify, Thorazine, Prozac, Ativan, Risperdal, Naltrexone,
and Claritin. This document lists "target behaviors" which include aggression like
behavior and inappropriate touch of others. There is a list of "proactive and reactive
strategies" to help in shaping Youth A's behavioral responses. This document also
outlines the processes of the "token economy” and other reinforcement to assist
Youth A. Reactive Strategies are outlined and if Youth A becomes aggressive
targeting staff, staff are to move to a safe location where they can still monitor Youth
A and keep the "verbal demand present". Staff are also to use the "wait strategy"
from a safe distance if Youth A is aggressive.
Crisis/Safety Plan for Youth A date of report 4/10/22. This document indicates
staff are to "utilize the safety care techniques of behavior management to deal with
Youth A for the following behaviors. Aggression, Property Destruction, Major Self-
Injurious Behavior, Self-Injurious Behavior and/or a safety separation has been
called. Staff are instructed to call 911 if all strategies are ineffective. This plan covers
both in the facility and during travel outside of the facility. The plan also provides in
detail staff's actions to be taken in both setting.
Residential Opportunities Inc. Best Practice: Medical Situations Training and
Checklist dated 8/2017. Emergency care is defined as an injury or illness that
poses an immediate risk to a youth's life or long-term health. Staff are to call 911 or
if safe transport youth to the closest Emergency Room. Urgent care is defined as not
meeting the emergency delimitation but requiring "quick action or attention" that
cannot wait for a scheduled appointment. The document indicates all staff are not to
call anyone off-site for an emergency but to make the call since they are present.
Another aspect of this policy/procedure is staff's response if the situation is not an
obvious emergency. Staff are to obtain "as much" information as possible from the
youth, check for injuries, bleeding, or pain and review the youth's medical protocols.
The document outlines staff's response to an emergency. An urgent situation is
outlined as unexplained pain or discomfort, fever above 101 degrees, vitals slightly

above or below normal, and if a prior injury worsens. Staff are to check a youth's
body if there are signs or complaints of pain or discomfort and contact the physician
or nurse for direction. Staff are also to complete all clinical documentation, incident
and accident report, medical observation sheet, staff log, and med book.
Safety Care Physical Safety with no date. This document outlines several different
techniques to use when staff are at risk for physical harm. The first is the "protective
shuffle" which provides a way for staff to maneuver safety. This technique also
involves the use of the hands to block possible strikes from the youth. The second
technique is the "shoulder check". This technique involves staff moving to the side
and behind the youth with one hand placed above the elbow and the other hand on
the back of the shoulder. Both arms are to be extended and if the youth turns to face
the staff, staff are to use the protective shuffle. A third technique is "stripping a
Grab". This involves staff being grabbed in a dangerous manner. Staff are to use to
technique to loosen the grab and once accomplished they should use the protective
shuffle.
Safety Care Physical Management with no date. This document states that
physical management is to be used only when necessary for safety and only with the
upmost care for the safety and wellbeing of the youth involved. Physical
management is to be used "only when there is no other safe alternative" available to
staff which also includes the protective shuffle. There are three criteria listed for
physical management which include the following. Imminent risk of serious harm to
the youth, no practical way to prevent that harm without physical intervention, and
the risk of not intervening must be greater than the risk of intervening. The 1-person
stability hold is outlined in this document and involves staff standing behind the
youth and either using both arms or one arm to hold the youth's single arm or both
arms while in a stand position.
Safety Care De-Escalation Process and Supportive Guide with no date. This
document outlines the techniques staff are to use to quickly change a youth's
directions of movement when they are headed towards something unsafe. This
technique is to be used if a youth is being aggressive and does not involve yanking,
pushing, or grabbing the youth. De-Escalation techniques involve three different
aspects, help, prompt, and wait. The help technique is to be used when the youth is
showing signs of aggression and involves giving the youth acceptable choices. The
prompt technique involves providing the desire behavior in a calm neutral tone and
allow 5-10 seconds for the youth to respond. The wait technique involves removing
others near the situation, using a safety stance which is placing yourself in a position
to monitor the youth while maintaining safety, and avoid reinforcing the negative
behaviors. Avoid eye contact and responding in a provocative manner. Other
aspects of the de-escalation process are to involve not rushing the youth and being
aware of the staff's own emotional behavior.
Incident, Accident, Illness, Death, or Fire Report for Youth A dated 6/4/22. This
document identifies Staff 1 as being involved/witnessing the incident. There are two

attachments describing the incident which will be reviewed below. First aid provided
included "monitoring for swelling/bruising, offered ice pack, and offered prn for pain".
The staff identified as providing first aid included Staff 7, Staff 9, and Staff 10. This
document also indicates Staff 1 is prohibited from working with Youth A "after
6/4/22". This document is signed by Case Manager on 6/4/22. The first attachment
is dated 6/4/22 and is signed by Case Manager. This document outlines a report
by Staff 1 after his shift ended and by phone with Case Manager. Staff 1 reported
Youth A was standing near the dining room doors when he began aggressing. Youth
A was kicking, punching, and head-butting before slipping on water. Youth A stood
up and continued aggressing before slipping once more. Staff 1 also reported there
were no other staff present although, Staff 2 heard the fall and opened the dining
room door to check on the situation. Youth A continued with his aggression until the
next prescribed staff change and until around 4:40 pm. This is the time Youth A said
Staff 1 had hit him before stating later that Staff 1 had pushed him, causing injury to
his arm. Case Manager asked where his arm was hurt, and he indicated the inside
of his left elbow. Youth A minimized the use of his left arm and had some bruising
on his upper arm and upper right chest. Case Manager reported Youth A has self-
injuring bruising and much of his current bruising appeared to be the same. Youth A
was given prn for pain and an ice pack. Youth A requested an "ambulance ride" to
the hospital. Staff are documented as being directed to continue to monitor Youth A
for worsening pain, swelling or lack of improvement on the injury.
